Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was about to grab my toolkit. It was Jamie, my closest friend, texting, “Rough day. Can you talk?” I could almost hear the exhaustion in her words. I knew she needed me to listen, to be present, to offer the kind of support only a good friend can give. But as I glanced at the machines humming in the corner, I felt a different kind of pressure. They’d missed their last service, and now the temperature readings were creeping higher than they should. If I didn’t get to them soon, we could be looking at a costly breakdown, and everyone would be asking why I hadn’t acted sooner.

I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the reply button, heart pounding. Jamie was counting on me to be there for her, but so was my team, in a completely different way. I felt torn, the weight of both expectations pressing down on me, knowing that whatever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
